segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase a process working set security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase a process working set security policy setting.

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase a process working set security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Increase a process working set security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users can increase or decrease the size of the working set of a process.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users can increase or decrease the size of the working set of a process.

segment.source: The working set of a process is the set of memory pages currently visible to the process in physical RAM.
segment.target: The working set of a process is the set of memory pages currently visible to the process in physical RAM.

segment.source: These pages are resident, and they are available for an application to use without triggering a page fault.
segment.target: These pages are resident, and they are available for an application to use without triggering a page fault.

segment.source: The minimum and maximum working set sizes affect the virtual memory paging behavior of a process.
segment.target: The minimum and maximum working set sizes affect the virtual memory paging behavior of a process.

segment.source: You should make users aware that adverse performance issues may occur if they modify this security setting.
segment.target: You should make users aware that adverse performance issues may occur if they modify this security setting.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, standard users have this right.
segment.target: By default, standard users have this right.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features, tools, and guidance to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the computer is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Settings are applied in the following order through a Group Policy Object (GPO), which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.
segment.target: When a local setting is greyed out, it indicates that a GPO currently controls that setting.

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Increasing the working set size for a process decreases the amount of physical memory that is available to the rest of the system.
segment.target: Increasing the working set size for a process decreases the amount of physical memory that is available to the rest of the system.

segment.source: Increase user’s awareness about the impact of increasing the working set of a process and how to recognize that their system is adversely affected if they change this setting.
segment.target: Increase user’s awareness about the impact of increasing the working set of a process and how to recognize that their system is adversely affected if they change this setting.

segment.source: Allowing standard users to increase the working set of a process is the default configuration.
segment.target: Allowing standard users to increase the working set of a process is the default configuration.
